author: Xu, X., Zheng, X., Sullivan, C., Wang, X., Xing, L., Wang, Y., Zhang, X., O'Connor, J.K., Zhang, F., Pan, Y.
title: A bizarre Jurassic maniraptoran theropod with preserved evidence of membranous wings
abstract: Analysis of Yi qi reveals membranous wing structure alongside feathers, providing insights into the diversity of flight-related adaptations in theropod dinosaurs.

author: Prum, R.O., Brush, A.H.
title: The evolutionary origin and diversification of feathers
abstract: A developmental model for feather evolution proposes that feathers evolved through a series of developmental stages from simple filaments to complex pennaceous structures.

author: Ibrahim, N., Maganuco, S., Dal Sasso, C., Fabbri, M., Auditore, M., Bindellini, G., Martill, D.M., Zouhri, S., Mattarelli, D.A., Unwin, D.M., Wiemann, J., Bonadonna, D., Amane, A., Jakubczak, J., Joger, U., Lauder, G.V., Pierce, S.E.
title: Tail-propelled aquatic locomotion in a theropod dinosaur
abstract: Discovery of Spinosaurus tail vertebrae reveals a paddle-like tail adapted for aquatic propulsion, confirming semi-aquatic lifestyle.

author: Houssaye, A., Scheyer, T.M., Kolb, C., Fischer, V., Sander, P.M.
title: A new look at ichthyosaur long bone microanatomy and histology: implications for their adaptation to an aquatic life
abstract: Microanatomical analysis reveals bone density adaptations in marine reptiles for buoyancy control.

author: Wedel, M.J.
title: Vertebral pneumaticity, air sacs, and the physiology of sauropod dinosaurs
abstract: Extensive pneumaticity in sauropod vertebrae indicates the presence of an avian-like respiratory system with air sacs.

author: Benson, R.B.J., Campione, N.E., Carrano, M.T., Mannion, P.D., Sullivan, C., Upchurch, P., Evans, D.C.
title: Rates of dinosaur body mass evolution indicate 170 million years of sustained ecological innovation on the avian stem lineage
abstract: Analysis of body mass evolution in dinosaurs reveals sustained miniaturization along the avian stem lineage.

author: Witmer, L.M., Ridgely, R.C.
title: New insights into the brain, braincase, and ear region of tyrannosaurs (Dinosauria, Theropoda), with implications for sensory organization and behavior
abstract: CT analysis of tyrannosaur braincases reveals enlarged olfactory bulbs and cochlear ducts, indicating acute senses of smell and hearing.

author: Zelenitsky, D.K., Therrien, F., Kobayashi, Y.
title: Olfactory acuity in theropods: palaeobiological and evolutionary implications
journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
abstract: Comparative analysis of theropod olfactory bulb sizes indicates T. rex had olfactory acuity exceeding most modern birds.

author: Stevens, K.A.
title: Binocular vision in theropod dinosaurs
abstract: Analysis of skull morphology reveals T. rex had 55° of binocular overlap, exceeding modern alligators and most birds of prey.

author: Kawabe, S., Hattori, S.
title: Complex neurovascular systems in the dentary of Tyrannosaurus rex
abstract: High-resolution CT reveals complex sensory systems in tyrannosaur jaws, suggesting sensitive bite force control.

author: Motani, R., Rothschild, B.M., Wahl, W.
title: Large eyeballs in diving ichthyosaurs
abstract: Analysis of ichthyosaur scleral rings reveals large eyes adapted for low-light aquatic environments.

author: Sampson, S.D.
title: New Perspectives on Horned Dinosaurs: The Royal Tyrrell Museum Ceratopsian Symposium
abstract: Comprehensive volume on ceratopsian biology, evolution, and paleobiology from the 2007 symposium.

author: Ibrahim, N., Sereno, P.C., Dal Sasso, C., Maganuco, S., Fabbri, M., Martill, D.M., Zouhri, S., Myhrvold, N., Iurino, D.A.
title: Semiaquatic adaptations in a giant predatory dinosaur
abstract: New Spinosaurus fossils reveal adaptations for aquatic life including short hind limbs, paddle feet, and dense bone.

author: Cuff, A.R., Rayfield, E.J.
title: Feeding mechanics in spinosaurid theropods and extant crocodilians
abstract: Biomechanical analysis reveals spinosaurids used crocodilian-like lateral head movements for prey capture.

author: Gong, E., Martin, L.D., Burnham, D.A., Falk, A.R.
title: The birdlike raptor Sinornithosaurus was venomous
journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
abstract: Grooved teeth and facial structure of Sinornithosaurus suggest a venomous bite, though this interpretation is debated.

author: Gianechini, F.A., Apesteguía, S., Landini, W., Finotti, F., Juárez-Valieri, R., Zanno, L.E.
title: New abelisaurid remains from the Cretaceous of Patagonia and comments on the origin of venom in theropods
abstract: Discussion of venom evolution in theropods and alternative interpretations of grooved teeth.

author: Weishampel, D.B.
title: Acoustic analyses of potential vocalization in lambeosaurine dinosaurs (Reptilia: Ornithischia)
abstract: First acoustic analysis suggesting lambeosaurine crests functioned as resonating chambers for vocalization.

author: Diegert, C.F., Williamson, T.E.
title: A digital acoustic model of the lambeosaurine hadrosaur Parasaurolophus tubicen
abstract: Digital reconstruction of Parasaurolophus crest acoustics demonstrates low-frequency sound production capability.

author: Bailey, J.B.
title: Neural spine elongation in dinosaurs: sailbacks or buffalo-backs?
abstract: Analysis of neural spine morphology in multiple taxa suggests various functions including thermoregulation and display.

author: Ibrahim, N., Sereno, P.C., Varricchio, D.J., Martill, D.M., Dutheil, D.B., Unwin, D.M., Baidder, L., Larsson, H.C.E., Zouhri, S., Kaoukaya, A.
title: Geology and paleontology of the Upper Cretaceous Kem Kem Group of eastern Morocco
abstract: Comprehensive monograph on the Kem Kem fossil assemblage including detailed Spinosaurus anatomy.

author: Vickaryous, M.K., Russell, A.P.
title: A redescription of the skull of Euoplocephalus tutus (Archosauria: Ornithischia): a foundation for comparative and systematic studies of ankylosaurian dinosaurs
journal: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
abstract: Detailed anatomical description of ankylosaurid skull including osteoderm arrangement and structure.

author: Arbour, V.M., Zanno, L.E., Gates, T.
title: Ankylosaurian dinosaur palaeoenvironmental associations were influenced by extirpation, sea-level fluctuation, and geodispersal
abstract: Analysis of ankylosaurid distribution and environmental preferences through time.

author: Fowler, D.W., Freedman, E.A., Scannella, J.B., Kambic, R.E.
title: The predatory ecology of Deinonychus and the origin of flapping in birds
abstract: Analysis of Deinonychus pedal morphology suggests sickle claws were used for pinning prey, not slashing.

author: Manning, P.L., Payne, D., Pennicott, J., Barrett, P.M., Ennos, R.A.
title: Dinosaur killer claws or climbing crampons?
abstract: Biomechanical testing reveals sickle claws were optimized for grip rather than slashing.

author: Arbour, V.M.
title: Estimating impact forces of tail club strikes by ankylosaurid dinosaurs
abstract: Biomechanical models estimate ankylosaurid tail clubs could generate impacts exceeding bone fracture thresholds.

author: Carpenter, K.
title: Redescription of Ankylosaurus magniventris Brown 1908 (Ankylosauridae) from the Upper Cretaceous of the Western Interior of North America
abstract: Comprehensive redescription of Ankylosaurus including tail club morphology and function.

author: Snively, E., Cox, A.
title: Structural mechanics of pachycephalosaur crania permitted head-butting behavior
abstract: Finite element analysis suggests pachycephalosaur domes could withstand head-butting impacts.

author: Peterson, J.E., Vittore, C.P.
title: Cranial pathologies in a specimen of Pachycephalosaurus
abstract: Lesions on Pachycephalosaurus domes suggest agonistic behavior involving head contact.

author: Erickson, G.M., Makovicky, P.J., Currie, P.J., Norell, M.A., Yerby, S.A., Brochu, C.A.
title: Gigantism and comparative life-history parameters of tyrannosaurid dinosaurs
abstract: Bone histology reveals T. rex gained over 2kg per day during adolescent growth spurt.

author: Sander, P.M., Clauss, M.
title: Sauropod gigantism
abstract: Overview of factors enabling dinosaur gigantism including respiratory and metabolic adaptations.

author: Benton, M.J., Csiki, Z., Grigorescu, D., Redelstorff, R., Sander, P.M., Stein, K., Weishampel, D.B.
title: Dinosaurs and the island rule: The dwarfed dinosaurs from Haţeg Island
abstract: Documentation of insular dwarfism in Romanian dinosaurs including Magyarosaurus and Telmatosaurus.

author: Sander, P.M., Mateus, O., Laven, T., Knötschke, N.
title: Bone histology indicates insular dwarfism in a new Late Jurassic sauropod dinosaur
abstract: Europasaurus histology confirms mature size was genuinely dwarfed, not simply juvenile.

author: Maxwell, W.D., Ostrom, J.H.
title: Taphonomy and paleobiological implications of Tenontosaurus-Deinonychus associations
abstract: Analysis of Deinonychus-Tenontosaurus associations suggests coordinated pack hunting behavior.

author: Roach, B.T., Brinkman, D.L.
title: A reevaluation of cooperative pack hunting and gregariousness in Deinonychus antirrhopus and other nonavian theropod dinosaurs
journal: Bulletin of the Peabody Museum of Natural History
abstract: Critical reanalysis questions pack hunting interpretation, suggesting mobbing or coincidental aggregation.

author: Holtz, T.R. Jr.
title: A critical re-appraisal of the obligate scavenging hypothesis for Tyrannosaurus rex and other tyrant dinosaurs
abstract: Comprehensive analysis of tyrannosaur feeding ecology and hunting capability.

author: Thomas, D.A., Northrope, S.A.
title: Ontogenetic niche shifts in megaherbivorous dinosaurs could drive tyrannosaur gigantism
abstract: Analysis of tyrannosaur size changes through ontogeny and ecological implications.

author: Schmitz, L., Motani, R.
title: Nocturnality in dinosaurs inferred from scleral ring and orbit morphology
abstract: Scleral ring analysis reveals most dinosaurs were diurnal while some pterosaurs and theropods were nocturnal.

author: Choiniere, J.N., Neenan, J.M., Schmitz, L., Ford, D.P., Chapelle, K.E.J., Balanoff, A.M., Sipla, J.S., Georgi, J.A., Walsh, S.A., Norell, M.A., Xu, X., Clark, J.M., Benson, R.B.J.
title: Evolution of vision and hearing modalities in theropod dinosaurs
abstract: Analysis of inner ear and eye socket morphology reveals sensory evolution in theropod lineages.

author: Grady, J.M., Enquist, B.J., Dettweiler-Robinson, E., Wright, N.A., Smith, F.A.
title: Evidence for mesothermy in dinosaurs
abstract: Growth rate analysis suggests dinosaurs had intermediate metabolic rates between reptiles and mammals.

author: Legendre, L.J., Guénard, G., Botha-Brink, J., Cubo, J.
title: Palaeohistological evidence for ancestral high metabolic rate in archosaurs
abstract: Bone histology across archosaurs suggests high metabolic rates were ancestral to the group.

author: Seymour, R.S.
title: Maximal aerobic and anaerobic power generation in large crocodiles versus mammals: implications for dinosaur gigantothermy
abstract: Comparison of power output in large ectotherms and endotherms, implications for dinosaur physiology.

author: Eagle, R.A., Tütken, T., Martin, T.S., Tripati, A.K., Fricke, H.C., Connely, M., Cifelli, R.L., Eiler, J.M.
title: Dinosaur body temperatures determined from isotopic (13C-18O) ordering in fossil biominerals
abstract: Clumped isotope thermometry reveals dinosaur body temperatures between 36-38°C.

author: Bates, K.T., Falkingham, P.L.
title: Estimating maximum bite performance in Tyrannosaurus rex using multi-body dynamics
abstract: Multi-body dynamics simulation estimates T. rex bite force at 35,000-57,000 Newtons, the highest of any terrestrial animal.

author: Erickson, G.M., Gignac, P.M., Steppan, S.J., Lappin, A.K., Vliet, K.A., Brueggen, J.D., Inouye, B.D., Kledzik, D., Webb, G.J.W.
title: Insights into the ecology and evolutionary success of crocodilians revealed through bite-force and tooth-pressure experimentation
abstract: Comparative analysis of bite forces in extant crocodilians provides context for understanding dinosaur bite force evolution.
